column1: Before 1 January 2021, will the Barakah nuclear power plant begin to supply electricity to the United Arab Emirates (UAE) power grid?
column6: ['Business', 'Technology', 'Environment']
column11: In an attempt to diversify its energy supply, the UAE has been constructing a nuclear power plant in cooperation with the Korea Electric Power Corp. (Bloomberg, World Nuclear Association). The first of four reactors has an operating license and is undergoing testing (Power Engineering, ME Construction News). Testing alone would not count.

column6: Finally reach the outcome, not sure if the production for Now needed "commercial" power will occur before the 31st instead of the Probability statement of power to the grid. Inasmuch as the ascension testing is complete and it is providing power to the grip.

With the completion of grid synchronization, reactor operators will begin the process of gradually raising Unit 1’s power levels, known as power ascension testing. The testing will be conducted under the oversight of the UAE’s independent nuclear regulator, the Federal Authority for Nuclear Regulation, which has conducted more than 280 inspections since the start of Barakah’s development, according to ENEC.

Connected to grid, but is it supplying electricity (beyond testing)? Sounds like PAT testing continues. Not sure how long that takes - have seen references to +1 months. Full commercial operation is planned by end of year - but has not happened yet. Per question “testing alone would not count”. “With the integration and connection complete, Unit 1’s nuclear operators will begin the process of gradually raising the power levels, known as Power Ascension Testing, PAT. Throughout this process, the Unit 1 systems follow international best practice to safely progress and test the unit as it proceeds towards full electricity production. Once the process is completed, Unit 1 will deliver, at full capacity, abundant baseload electricity to power the growth and prosperity of the UAE for decades to come.”

Criticality was reached 2 days ago. [1] As I wrote in a previous comment, the other two APR-1400 reactors took 12 and 4 months to become operational after reaching criticality. [2]

Reactor started. Soon it will provide power to grid in a testing phase. To become commercial by end of the year. https://www.thenational.ae/uae/uae-becomes-first-arab-nation-to-produce-nuclear-energy-1.1057355

Little unclear why the percentage chance has risen so much... reaching criticality marks a 4-8 month mark to supplying energy based on prior data (@tmcgraw). 4 months puts us at the beginning of December. There's certainly tons of uncertainty around how the region will react, which might delay putting power out to the grid. Not to mention, there's a pandemic going on.

Although the plant has experienced delays they are small compared to other similar reactors and criticality has now been reached meaning remaining hurdles to generate electricity are not highly complex nuclear engineering ones
Critical milestone reached!
(Controlled) Nuclear fission reportedly "has begun" at Barakah plant (unit 1).
I'm forecasting downwards, with part of the idea being that no news is bad news.
https://www.neimagazine.com/news/newsbarakah-2-completed-at-uae-nuclear-plant-8029679

Unit 1 has been completed since 2018 and fuel assembly loading was completed this March. [1] My understanding is that power ascension testing must be completed before the plant start supplying electricity. [2] The IAEA commissioning guideline for nuclear power plants says that "Successful completion of core physics tests, power ascension tests and other plant acceptance tests may take six months or more from initial core loading and removal of the shutdown guarantee. During this initial period of operation, it is normal practice to plan a short outage (e.g. one month) or multiple short outages to clear all items still unresolved." [3] I'm not clear on what core loading means but I think it's synonymous with fuel loading (could also mean reaching criticality, which hasn't happened yet at Barakah afaik). So 6 months from March (September) would be the minimum amount of time if I understand the terminology correctly. However, if core loading refers to reaching criticality, Barakah likely won't open by 2021 as I can't find a source saying that criticality has been achieved (in May the CEO of ENEC said that criticality was "a couple weeks or a month or so" away). [4] Relevant historical background: there are 2 APR-1400's currently being used, both built by KEPCO (wikipedia lists Shin-Hanul 1 as operational but I don't think this is true, see [6]). [5] It took 12 and 4 months for the plants to open after first reaching criticality. [6]

While the general consensus in terms of the written word is overall positive for the Barakah's opening and use, there appear to be more and more pieces coming out of the middle east that are arguing against the plant, and highlighting why the Barakah plant is wrong for the region. I've revised my prediction downward, as I am not as confident as I was earlier in the month that this will go through by the end of the year.
An initial forecast with the following key drivers:
https://www.thenational.ae/uae/government/barakah-uae-completes-construction-of-nuclear-plant-s-second-unit-1.1049272
It seems the tests were good, now they need certification to start operations, so I am confident that by year end the plant will start the distribution from the first reactor.

From available information, it would seem almost certain. However, I'm just sort of a pessimist about big construction projects, especially nuclear plants. Public statements about project status always seem to be on the very most optimistic edge of reality. All it would take is one failed test, accident, bad PR, etc, to push the schedule back a few months.

Likely due to increased electricity needs cause by increase stay-at-home activities, and political pressure compounded by recently made statements. Significant risk that rushing might result in faults or issues causing a delay. In addition, the risk retaliation from or targeting by hostile actors is not insignificant.

Going off of what @RRG has mentioned (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1068911) previously, I agree with him, but feel much more confident as there is enough time between now and the cutoff (1/1/2021) that the UAE will be able to negotiate some consensus with their neighbors.
Sources in the question information are pretty good. There are many references noting that the plant is on schedule and should achieve criticality soon.
The trajectory suggests testing at the end of the year, but not supply given safety standards needing to be met in advance.
The Barakah nuclear power plant will be a landmark of the Arab world, and an important milestone in the UAE's path towards generating 25% of their total energy requirements in the medium term.
I’ve not read up much on this topic but seems unlikely in the world of isolation in which we now live. Failure of safety measures within nuclear power may contribute as well.

It will depend when they actually achieve criticality , from there it is three months to connect to the grid as we see in Kudankulam or Guangdong https://www.world-nuclear-news.org/Articles/Second-Chinese-EPR-achieves-criticality https://www.world-nuclear-news.org/Articles/World-s-second-EPR-starts-operations https://www.livemint.com/Industry/BpF607uRkjDuZxNOC1sHHK/Kudankulam-nuclear-power-plant-attains-criticality.html https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kudankulam_Nuclear_Power_Plant https://www.neimagazine.com/news/newsuae-nuclear-power-plant-to-achieve-criticality-very-soon-7919639
Nuclear fuel has been loaded.

https://energycentral.com/news/uae-crown-prince-hails-%E2%80%98remarkable-progress%E2%80%99-barakah-nuclear-plant During a tour of the Barakah Nuclear Energy Plant, UAE Crown Prince Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan hailed the “remarkable progress” being made at the Emirati facility, the first of its kind in the Arab world, and stressed the need to go ahead with the project despite the exceptional circumstances created by the coronavirus. It is being built by a consortium led by the Korea Electric Power Corporation. KEPCO stock is operating with a negative income of -787,798,000 this quater , with pressure to deliver to its shareholders I think it will motivate KEPCO to complete the project. https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/015760.KS/financials?p=015760.KS

In 2010, the UAE announced plans to build its first nuclear power plant as part of a new energy strategy to generate 50 percent of its power from renewable sources by 2050. Construction of the Barakah plant began in April 2013. According to an analysis based on data released by the IAEA, the world’s foremost nuclear watchdog, it takes an average of 7.5 years to build a nuclear power plant. Taking this average, we could expect the plant to be finished by September 2020 which gives us a clue to the January 2021 time element contained in the question. [1]

(Initial forecast:) Per forecaster comments below plus sources listed it currently appears more likely than not that operations may begin by year-end. Testing issues or possibly widespread COVID infections among key personnel could conceivably cause setbacks.

Although there have been previous delays to this project, the timing from fuel loading to commercial operations judging by the reactors built in Korea ranges from a year to 6 months. Fuel loading was completed on Unit 1 in March of this year (1) which would signal that the plant is nearly ready to go critical, delays tend to happen before fuel is loaded. I am not aware of the fuel from a nuclear reactor ever been removed before operations begin (in a commercial reactor). Although there can be difficulties in connecting the plant to the grid, this is a fairly regular operation and there are Korean engineers there who will have experience of these difficulties.
The nukes ready to go...sanctioned by WANO...geopolitics aside you dont idle a reactor thats met all as builts and safeguards...you pull rods !
All seems to be progressing nicely. High probability they will be adding power to grid prior to the end of the year.
